name: Invisible Work in the Digital Economy
description:
Are your 10 minute deliveries worth the labour? 

Cycling through the streets of London, artist Beth Fox's 12 lemons documents her experience working for a food delivery company. We will screen this video essay to reflect on the gig economy and the tightly controlled labour behind one-click food deliveries.

It will be followed by a discussion on the physical, emotional, and psychological effects of platform work across sectors such as food delivery, data annotation, and content moderation. Our panelists will discuss the difficult nature of such work and the systems behind the gig and platform sectors' labour issues, while touching upon social security for platform labour, as well as the developments necessary for safe and dignified work.

name: In the pipeline: On AI labour
description:
What does it take to keep AI running?

AI chatbots, self-driving cars, and social media platforms may appear seamless and autonomous, but they depend on vast networks of human labour. A large workforce of people, scattered across the world, provides data for training AI models, and removes harmful content released online, among other kinds of work. They often work in very harsh conditions; with low pay, inadequate support and social security, under uncertain terms, and often at great personal risk.

‘In the pipeline’ is a card game that tries to demonstrate the problems workers face in their roles in content moderation and AI labour. Players will navigate these industries while enduring different hazards and bearing related costs. As players navigate shifting industry demands, workplace hazards, and economic uncertainty, they confront the invisible costs behind “intelligent” systems.

Through play, the workshop opens up conversations around precarity, advocacy, and the structural changes needed to imagine fairer technological futures.

name: Of Minds, Moods, and Meals: Understanding the Science of Emotions and Food
description:
Why does sugar feel irresistible? Why does loneliness change what we crave? And how can a single smell instantly transport you home?

Of Minds, Moods, and Meals explores food as a meeting point between biology, emotion, neuroscience, and behaviour. Moving from neural reward pathways and microbial chemistry to inherited histories, we see how appetite is shaped long before it reaches the plate. Cravings are wired by evolution, moods are influenced by the gut, disgust protects and divides, and culture teaches us what is desirable, or forbidden. Food is not only nourishment; it is regulation, identity, attachment, and hierarchy. 

Join our Experimentor Sai, for a walkthrough tracing these connections across body, brain, and society. 

Come curious. Leave seeing your plate differently.

name: Breaking Down the Artist's Recipe
description:
Every artist has a recipe: a process of gathering ingredients, making creative choices, and shaping how their ideas are shared. Just as our bodies digest food, artists digest their experiences, breaking down observations, narratives, culture, and environments into creative work.

This walkthrough takes you behind the scenes of CALORIE, exploring how artists transform everyday experiences into art. By looking closely at their “ingredients,” flavour profiles, textures, and choice of medium, we trace the journey from idea to finished work and uncover the many modes of expression artists use to make sense of food, culture, and lived experience.

Join our experimenters, Nirupama and Shreya, for a playful and participatory walkthrough that treats art-making as explorations, creativity as a shared process, and meaning-making as something we all do every day.
